data.event: As of the 2010 United States Census, the township's population was 23,033, reflecting an increase of 780 (+3.5%) from the 22,253 counted in the 2000 Census, which had in turn increased by 1,727 (+8.4%) from the 20,526 counted in the 1990 Census.

As of the 2010 United States Census, the township's population was 23,033, reflecting an increase of 780 (+3.5%) from the 22,253 counted in the 2000 Census, which had in turn increased by 1,727 (+8.4%) from the 20,526 counted in the 1990 Census.

event.title: was incorporated as a township by an act of the New Jersey Legislature on March 1, 1847

data.event: Medford was incorporated as a township by an act of the New Jersey Legislature on March 1, 1847, from portions of Evesham Township, based on the results of a referendum held that day.
Medford was incorporated as a township by an act of the New Jersey Legislature on March 1, 1847, from portions of Evesham Township, based on the results of a referendum held that day.

event.title: was sold to Samual Coles in 1670

data.event: The area known as Medford was sold to Samual Coles in 1670, in all it consisted of 900 acres (3.6 kmÂ²).

event.title: the next few years the Braddock, Prickett, Stratton, Branin, and Wilkins families moved

data.event: Within the next few years the Braddock, Prickett, Stratton, Branin, and Wilkins families moved to the area (many of whom continue to live in the area today).

event.title: include Oliphant's Mill, Christopher's Mill and the Shamong Trail (now

data.event: Many of the building and roads built between the sale of the land and the American Revolutionary War are still in existence, which include Oliphant's Mill, Christopher's Mill and the Shamong Trail (now known as Stokes Road).
